name: Abdi Nazemian
bio: I write books (Only This Beautiful Moment, Like A Love Story) & write / produce film & TV. I believe in divas & diverse storytelling.

bio_keywords.entity: like a love story & write produce film & tv

social_posts.post_text: Yesterday, after taking the kids to taekwondo and gymnastics, we wandered into a new bookstore. Because I'm a bookshop obsessive, I asked when it opened and found out it's a brand new bookstore, and that while it carries all sorts of well-curated books, it's focused on young adult literature. And then I found out that the bookstore's owner is 16 YEARS OLD (!!). When I offered to sign any books of mine they had in stock, Annabelle said Like a Love Story was one of her favorite books, and this photo was taken. The world often feels like a deeply gloomy place, but magical moments like this keep me hopeful and optimistic. It was so beautiful to have my own kids share my pride in what I do, and to see a young reader not much older than them start her own business. If you're looking for a bookstore to buy from, please consider Annabelle's in Studio City. It's a truly special place. My Gen X heart is so moved by a teenager opening up a brick and mortar bookshop, selling paper books. Books aren't going anywhere, and neither is hope.

The many moods of ‘22. I felt all the emotions this year and I leave the year feeling gratitude for the things that keep me going: family, friends, creativity, adventure, laughter, art. Happy new year friends. Let’s fill the world with love and empathy this year.

Relieved, nervous but very excited to finally announce what I've been working on for over a year – my new podcast, TRACKS OF OUR QUEERS.

Each episode, a fascinating guest discusses one song, one album and one artist that have resonated with them as a queer person. 

The sensational @abdaddy aka Abdi Nazemian, award-winning author and film/TV producer, is my very first guest and I can't wait for you to hear his choices. 

You can find the podcast wherever you listen, and follow on the gram at @tracksofourqueerspod 🫦

I’ve very much enjoyed a social media break but I gotta come back ‘cause I have a paperback coming next month and a brand new book coming in May, and I want all of you to read the hell out of them. Some of you will be moved and some of you will accuse me of being a “groomer” and threaten me for daring to talk to teens about sexuality and self-acceptance. Anyway here’s a photo of me from our kids’ birthday party that captures my intention for this year which is to diabolically devour everything that gets in my way, beginning (obviously) with myself.

This is the soundtrack of the last year of my life. I can’t really thank musicians enough for gifting us moments like these. A guide. 1) We puzzled, and puzzled and puzzled. For each session, Rumi ran his finger along our record collection and we listened to whatever he landed on when we yelled stop. We cycled through artists the kids know and love (Kate, Lana, Billie) and new discoveries for them (The Cure, Toquinho, Litsa Diamanti). These are the memories I’ll cherish forever. 2) The most fabulous drag queen Grinch ever work-work-working to Rihanna in Mexico City. Beyond. 3 & 4) My favorite albums of 2022, and some of them on vinyl ‘cause you gotta give your favorites more than streams from companies that don’t pay artists fairly. 5) Piano lessons with our son, truly a highlight of life these days. Decoding the magic of favorites like Tori and Lana is so meaningful. 6 & 7) Photos from concerts. These last few years haven’t fed me as much live music as I need, but I managed to see Grace Jones (with CHVRCHES and the epicccc Charlotte Adigéry), one of my biggest crushes Father John Misty (with divine Suki Waterhouse) and at long last, Elvis Costello (with Nick Lowe). Ready for a lot more this year. 8 & 9) Madonna making the people come together, always and forever. 10) Me and Disco chilling on Love Street ‘cause no one's gonna take our soul away, we’re living like Jim Morrison (side note: started rewatching The Doors, best musical biopic ever). 🎵🪩

Last night, I had the honor of helping present an award to West Hollywood Mayor Sepi Shyne, the first out LGBTQ Iranian elected ANYWHERE. When asked to speak I was quick to tell the organizers I was no authority on the situation in Iran, nor did I feel comfortable speaking on behalf of all Iranians. I love storytelling because it's about telling one specific story in hopes of creating greater empathy, and I'll keep telling queer Iranian stories as my personal form of activism because it feels true to me and what I can offer the world. This is why, when my kid woke up this morning asking if it was okay to say he has nothing in common with Katniss Everdeen for his school book project, I rolled myself out of bed and said, "You both have siblings and families you love. You're both brave. And also, how about your common humanity? You have that in common with every character in every story ever written. Start there." For the most part, what you'll find on my Instagram is a reflection of my life as one individual gay Iranian who mostly thinks about storytelling, parenting and divas. If you're looking for updates on the bravery of the Iranian people and the atrocities of the regime, many are doing the job the media should be. Like: @taragrammy @moj @royazara @iamnazaninnour @tarakangarlou 
@yelmjouie @yasharali @ninaansary @golfarahani @nazaninboniadi. I'm sure I forgot some. And for more vibrant queer Iranianness in your feed, follow a few people who are sharing their lives here and creating greater empathy through their openness: @pooyaland @hushi5 @raminehajipour @matthewnouriel @shawndeeeez @amiryassofficial @save_taste, @adibkhorram @arvinahmadi @sara.farizan (obV so many more).
I
(side note: let it be known that posing like Linda Evangelista in front of a step and repeat is not an endorsement of the views of every sponsor, just as the inevitable book promotion I'll be doing for the rest of the year doesn't mean I don't support the striking workers at my publisher, just as posting on this platform is no endorsement of its parent company’s misinformation-spewing spiritually-bankrupt policies. We do the best we can…)

I try to exist in a constant state of reverent irreverence but sometimes other people's negativity must be called out. I found out another school district is trying to ban Like a Love Story, a book that hopefully fills a gap in our collective education when it comes to queer history and HIV/AIDS. When I find out about book bans like these, or read an otherwise positive review of my work that calls out the sexual content as inappropriate for teenagers, I feel so many emotions:
I
Sadness for all the queer kids and teens, told that their sexuality or gender identity should be hidden. I know what it feels like to be that kid. It sucks. Anyone who wants to go back to a time when kids were taught shame, who thinks schools were better when kids were hazed and abused (see my last book The Chandler Legacies)... should really seek better spiritual guidance.
I
Anger because shame leads to so much unnecessary pain and suffering. Look up  queer suicide and addiction statistics. I personally have lost so many friends (and my first boyfriend) to the epidemic of shame in our community.
I
Pride because I never thought I'd get to be the person I am today with so much hate, often from my own communities.
I
Confusion at how we went from a world where my conservative parents took me to the Blond Ambition tour at 13 to a world where "liberal" Bill Maher consistently mocks what's happening in schools as if it's meaningless when it's life and death for these kids.
I
Pity (in better moments, empathy) for people who make hate/division such a huge part of their lives, often in the name of religion. No one who uses God to divide has experienced God's presence, which is pure love. I don't talk about this (too) often but for me, true creativity feels like listening to the divine. I wish everyone knew how healing that feels.
I
Annoyance because all my books seem to be defined by my “identity” instead of by what they're truly about: love, community, oneness.
I
Anyway, happy Oscar nomination day to all who celebrate, and please focus on what really matters in this wild world, which is that Madonna is going on a greatest hits tour. Take your kid to see her. It might save their lives.

THE CHANDLER LEGACIES is now out in paperback. Going to boarding school was a journey, writing the book was an odyssey, but now the book is flying solo without me into the hands of beautiful readers. I’ve seen the book described as the “WORST BOOK EVER!” And also as “So. Fucking. Amazing.” Some readers love every member of this found family and others want to “smack EVERY SINGLE CHARACTER IN THE WHOLE BOOK!” Some readers find it “painfully boring.” Others “could barely put this down!” For the record I love all these responses. As I tell our kids all the time, if art isn’t at least a little divisive, it’s probably not doing its job. The only response I don’t like is banning books. Don’t ban books, buy-borrow-share-love-hate-cherish them! On that note, don’t you want to pick up a paperback copy and decide for yourself if it’s dreadfully dull or unputdownable?

Book news and deep thoughts:

1) ONLY THIS BEAUTIFUL MOMENT received a starred review from Kirkus. An excerpt: "Nazemian expertly bridges the past and the present, exploring racism, homophobia, and relations between the United States and Iran… His elegant prose propels this historically resonant and culturally nuanced family drama. A stunning intergenerational coming-of-age story." The book is also a Junior Library Guild Gold Standard selection. Out May 9, but you can pre-order!

2) April 12, The Chandler Legacies... I mean LE CERCLE, will be disponible en France, country of my childhood. The Circle was one of my original titles for this book so I'm loving the French title. Photo of me at Paris’ most important landmark: PLACE DALIDA (type her name into Spotify and prepare for magic).

3) I'll be at YALLWEST again on April 29. Join us!

4) I've been bad about posting, but I’ve loved every panel / festival / event I've been a part of recently. I was especially inspired by a trip to Syracuse to speak at 3 different high schools. All remaining photos from Syracuse including me in my Lana shirt next to a Lana poster in a high school radio station. I get a lot of questions about the attacks on queer students, drag queens, the trans community. To anyone out there in a position to offer young people guidance and hope, please do it. For the record, the first person I came out to was a high school English teacher (in writing, obV), almost a decade before I came out to my parents. If I hadn't felt safe to come out to a teacher, who knows where I'd be right now? Perhaps, like so many of my friends, I wouldn't be here. The idea of forcing teachers to inform parents about their students' sexuality or gender identity is truly insidious. I hate it as a human and as a parent. Schools are meant to be safe spaces for students to experiment, learn, grow, ask-every-question. Students and educators need your support and it's gotta come in a deeper, more meaningful form than social-media-shaming (fuck shame). It's time to connect in a world of disconnection, build bridges in a world that's fractured, and help this inspiring new generation however we can. Let the great work begin.

The attacks on the queer community have become alarming and authors of queer books for young people have become one of the targets. Look, I spent the bulk of my formative years being shamed and stigmatized, so being attacked is my comfort zone. I'm more than happy to take the hate to make a better world for the youth. And I'm way past the point of being shamed. I'll never feel shame again. I love who I am and the life I created out of hard work, persistence, love and stardust. Never in a million years did I think I'd have the love I have in my life, a beautiful husband, the best kids in the world, a career filled with purpose and creativity. I've achieved everything I set out to, and I live unapologetically and empathically. In our home, we teach our children to empathize with everyone, including their bullies, and my bullies. So much of what I speak about when I speak at schools is self-forgiveness, but also empathy and forgiveness for those who hate us, both because I believe they can grow out of their hate, and even if they don't, living in a place of rage is no way to live. As I've aged, I've found more serenity than I've ever had before. I've found spirituality. I feel loved (by people and by God) and feel I finally know how to give love. Sometimes, the strange serenity I feel these days scares me. Because I lived so much of my life in a constant-state-of-wanting, serenity can make me feel like something's wrong. But it's not. All I can say is that what my life has taught me is that I'm much stronger than I ever thought I was. I can handle hate and like a fucking alchemist, I can turn it into love and art. Which isn't to say that I won't respond to this bullshit with campy irreverence and momentary anger. But it does mean I will never let online idiocy, hateful politicians or anyone else rob me of my belief system which is about unity. I'll take that with me wherever I go next.
I
And since this book is an ode to @madonna 👑 Thanks queen for teaching me how to take on criticism in style. You are the true blueprint.

Some follow-up thoughts from your (least) favorite mentally, emotionally and physically flexible Iranian queen on the book banning madness. I woke up to news that LIKE A LOVE STORY is banned in another district (alongside Toni Morrison?!) & that the same book was chosen by librarians in an NBC poll as one of the 13 best young adult books because it “shines a light on the young queer experience.” So first thanks to everyone supporting and to EVERY librarian/educator fighting against these hateful people. Now… thoughts… 
I
Some of you have said I should drown out the negativity and I usually do. But you try ignoring death threats, being called a groomer/pedophile, former CBS/Fox “journalist” Lara Logan calling you "disgusting" (she also traffics in election denialism & HIV/AIDS misinformation, so of course she wouldn't want young people learning about how people like her gleefully let a generation of queers die). I stand for unity but (Lana voice), don't mistake my kindness for weakness. And for all the "parents' rights" advocates, I'm a parent too. A VERY QUEER PARENT. But they don't care about us. Nor do they understand that a parents' first job is to put their own kids' rights and needs ahead of their own. My own kids have been horrified by what's been going on and have tried to jump online to defend me (not happening). Our daughter cried in the car about it, asked why people can't just accept others as they are? A question we should all be asking.
I
Some have told me this behavior is "just online." It's not. I've gotten complaints for in-person school visits. I don't share the messages or conversations I have with teens but trust that they're intense. This generation needs us. Others have suggested book bans are "good for business." Again, no. Schools and libraries are the core of this business. When they can't stock the book, it's very bad for business. And more importantly, it keeps the books out of the hands of the people who need them most. 
I
All the hate and fascism in this world is connected. Hate creates more hate, love creates more love. As my goddess Tori Amos says we need to "out-create" so that's what I'll be doing in between splits. 🙏🏽☮️

I need to post something that’s not (only) about book-banning-queer-hating-fascism so here’s my queen-of-disaster, my subconscious-in-human-form Lana Del Rey getting Tehran Takeout. I have questions. What’s Lana’s favorite khoresht? Does she drink doogh? Where does she stand on kashkeh bademjoon? Does she own a polo paz? Will her next album be called Lust for Gheymeh? Will she meet her boyfriend down at the kabob stand? When will she announce her album Did You Know There’s A Queer Community Suffering Under Iranian Boulevards? In all seriousness though, I think one of many reasons I love this magical artist is that her poetry and melodies remind me of whatever the fuck home is to me. A dash of Persian poetry, a sprig of French chanson, and a lot of American nihilistic idealism. And don’t forget, the Iranian women-led movement rages on and needs your support. Zan. Zendegi. Azadi. (autocorrect just changed Azadi to Arcadia, which makes it official. Lana is haunting both my subconscious and my phone). 
❤️
Photo 2 is me with the first (of countless) new Lana vinyls I bought + a keepsake from my honeymooooon with my husband, the smile our daughter puts on my face, the piano our son composes magic on, and the Stonewall Honor the American Library Association awarded to LIKE A LOVE STORY. All the love and creativity no book banner can take from me. It’s not about having someone to hate me anymore. This is the experience of bein’ an Iranian whore.
❤️
And big thanks to the students of Midwood High School for putting me in the BEST mood today and telling me I have “Uncle Stephen” energy (what a compliment). The kids are more than alright. They’re lighting the path forward for us all.

Obviously voted Yes to another WGA strike. Every other writer I know did the same. No writer wants to strike. I certainly don’t. I love what I’m beyond lucky to call a job so much. I want to work. But I also want that work valued fairly, and I want writers (and all artists) to be able to have financial stability as they embark on a life of creativity.
📖
This video is from November 2007. And while my knees are creakier, I’m ready to jump up and down and bang that drum again (hopefully with Joel Michaely as Norma Rae once more). Educate yourself about the issues at hand, about why our union matters, and think about how our society (de)values art, (de)values work, and has turned every individual into desperate gig workers desperately cobbling together a life. There’s a lot of misinformation out there, so if you’re looking for a good piece about what writers deserve, look up The Ankler’s The Writers’ Bill of Rights by Richard Rushfield. 
📖
Here’s an excerpt from the piece: “The lot of writers in Hollywood has never been one of power and glory. Shafting the writers in every possible way is a tradition as old as the industry itself. But in years past, that shafting had limits, enforced by union rules and a basic, if grudging, recognition that the business of “entertaining” required writing and writers. In today’s streaming hellscape, those facts are no longer acknowledged.”
📖
#WGASTRONG #unionstrong #writersofinstagram
📖
PS I want that Madonna Inn sweater again someone get it for me next time you go!!

Dispatch from a banned queen: I don’t usually share discussions or messages from teens for obvious reasons,  but with permission I’m (over)sharing some details from a recent high school visit. I hope this helps illustrate what the fascists are afraid of when they ban books like LIKE A LOVE STORY - my ode to ACT UP, Madonna and the queer community - and ban all queer discussion from schools (kids in Florida, you are loved). Queer youth need us right now. Please do your part to make this world a safe place for them. Scroll to the end for a photo from the BRILLIANT teens who wrote these notecards. The future is theirs, if we’re generous enough to give it to them. 
📚
Thank you @lambdaliterary for organizing this particular visit. Thank you @theauthorvillage for organizing school visits for me and so many others. Most of all thank you to the heroic educators standing up to threats and intimidation. First person I came out to was my English teacher, many many many years before I’d come out to my family. Without open hearted teachers I don’t know where I’d be. Not here that’s for sure. But since I’m still here, I’ll keep doing anything and everything I can to make this world a more loving and accepting place.

Ah London. I saw 8 shows. Then got diverticulitis and had to skip 3. But I got to see the hotness that is Paul Mescal in Streetcar alongside Patsy Ferran, who will be a superstar if there's any justice in the world (which there sometimes-rarely is… ). Saw Janet McTeer devour a modernized Phaedra and Sophie Okonedo devour Medea. Cried through A Little Life and Shirley Valentine (Sheridan Smith!! also if you haven't seen the movie version of Shirley Valentine, watch ASAP). Walked and walked and walked. Spent a whole day in queer archives contemplating how the issues facing our community now are sadly similar to the ones we faced decades ago. Saw beloved friends. Almost-boarded the Heathrow Express only to realize my flight was leaving from Gatwick. Tried to take the Gatwick Express but it was shut down. Got in one of those old-fashioned London taxis and told my cabbie to drive like he's in a James Bond movie. Took almost two hours, during which I told him about my life as a constantly-banned human, and he, an older-than-me Irish-British man, told me about his own Troubles. We covered Thatcher, Brexit, the Iranian revolution. Two days earlier, I met the most divine historian in the queer archives. Vivienne Westwood / Siouxsie Sioux energy. Both the cabbie and the punk historian told me the same thing at one point in our long chats: that the world needs more kindness and understanding right now. I agree. Also, more art. More curiosity. More bridge-building. At one point, the cabbie told me about his family's experiences during WWII and The Blitz. We pondered whether humans need mass tragedy to realize we're all one. But we're all going through a mass trauma event right now (you know, that pandemic that still isn't over) and it’s only divided us more. So maybe tragedy isn't the answer to unity. Maybe it really does come down to 1 moment of kindness and connection at a time. Barely made my flight back to NY. The stressful journey there was worth it for reminding me who I am, what I stand for. Yes, I feel Beef-levels of rage at least once a day, but I feel Shirley-Valentine-levels of love at least 100 times a day. A decent ratio. Onward hopefully toward enlightenment.

To all my fellow movie lovers, two new movies are out today that I'd love to put on your radar.

ARE YOU THERE GOD? IT'S ME, MARGARET is a truly-perfect-gift of a movie. I got to see an advance screening with our kids thanks to the magical Elisa Donovan. It led to the most incredible conversations, and I know it'll do the same for your family (and please, don't leave the boys at home, they need to see this film). Thank you to everyone involved but especially to Queen Mother Judy Blume.

SID IS DEAD is a hilarious-and-heartfelt high school comedy, directed beautifully by the superstar Eli Gonda (that's him with me in the photo), and produced by a dream team of producers that includes yours truly. I felt incredibly proud as I watched it last night alongside my beloved Jennifer Elia, and the cast and crew. It's in select theaters, and available on Apple, Amazon, and other platforms I probably haven't heard of 'cause I can't keep up anymore.

Want some other recommendations? There's a beautiful gay film called OF AN AGE on Peacock that includes an entire scene about Tori Amos (!!). BEEF is the best TV show I've seen in eons (and like Of an Age and Yellowjackets, it includes... TORI AMOS). The new Jessie Ware album is a disco masterpiece that channels MaDonnaSummer in the best way. And if you want more recent music, these artists have released my other favorite albums of the year so far: Lana Del Rey (obviously), Yaeji, Kelela, Yves Tumor, Shygirl, Fever Ray, Feist, Kali Uchis, Black Belt Eagle Scout, Caroline Polachek, Daughter. 

Support artists whenever and however you can, especially those who are about to... maybe... go on strike... 😭✊🏽

YALLWEST photo guide. 

1. Kelly from Bookcrushin brought me a copy of ONLY THIS BEAUTIFUL MOMENT to sign that was sold early by Barnes & Noble (don’t make a habit of this booksellers). I hadn’t seen a copy yet so I freaked out and Kelly now has the first signed copy. The text is the book’s starred Booklist review. Zoom in and read please. It’s the most beautiful review I’ve ever gotten for my favorite thing I’ve ever written. Now go buy the book please. 

2. With superstar George M. Johnson. Don’t read George’s work because it’s banned. Read it because it’s BRILLIANT.

3. Being Maurene Goo’s friend makes me feel like a homecoming queen. Get her new book. Get all her books.

4. With Persian royalty Shouka.

5. All laughs with Queen of Yallwest Melissa de la Cruz and the glorious Jason June joon (that’s your official Iranian name JJ).

6. Paneling with superstars.

The rest is me in a poncho provided by the festival’s other Queen @margaret_stohl ‘cause it was freezing in Santa Monica and also Joan Crawford because she’s in ONLY THIS BEAUTIFUL MOMENT and Gary Cooper alongside her ‘cause I was watching one of his movies (Design For Living) last night and I just like to look at him.

Have you made it this far? Here’s some of that Booklist review: « This story, told in three points of view from three generations of the same family, is nothing short of masterful. Moud and his family are multifaceted and exquisitely crafted, and the setting of Tehran is suffused with sumptuous food, dance, and poetry. The subject of prejudice against LGBTQ+ people in both America and Iran is woven into all three characters' stories, but Nazemian takes pains to highlight the courage borne by individuals in the face of oppressive regimes, holding them up as exemplars. This is the kind of story that young-adult literature is made for: a story of the heart, of the very real human struggles young people face and that adults try to-but never truly-forget. »

Look, there will be time for me to talk about the existential issues facing all writers, all artists, all workers, in this new world of alarming wealth disparity, of devaluing human worth, of rampant misinformation and hate, of interconnected crises. But right now, I’d like to share the words Tori Amos sang onstage at the Nokia Theater on December 16, 2007 (it’s now called the Microsoft Theater, and in a few years, maybe it’ll be the ChatGPT Theater, see... interconnected issues). Busy and I went backstage to meet Tori pre-show. We realized everyone but us had gifts for Tori, so we took off our strike pins, gave them to her as gifts, and explained how the issues facing writers were similar to those she faced when she fought the record companies. A very short time later, Tori took the stage and delivered this rant: “WRITERS. WRITERS. WHERE ARE YOU IN THIS FUCKING TOWN? WHEN ARE YOU GOING TO STAND UP AND STOP SUCKING THE COCK OF THE SMEGMA-INFESTED CORPORATE CLONE?... SEIZE THE POWER!” You know me, I’m all about empathy and oneness and taking care of our spiritual selves. But right now, it’s time to stand up and stop sucking the cock of the smegma-infested corporate clones who are destroying every aspect of this beautiful world with their dehumanizing greed. #WGASTRONG #UNIONSTRONG (p.s. if you want to help, you can donate to the Entertainment Community Fund, one of my husband’s clients who are helping writers in need of financial assistance)

Guess who’s doing his best to be a scintillating guest on Busy Philipps Is Doing Her Best’s new episode? Me! Honestly, doing my best is hard these days. Between the Like a Love Story book banning, the writers’ strike (photo of us is from the last strike), the imminent release of my favorite book I’ve written (Only This Beautiful Moment, out in 4 days), my new life as an honorary Brasileiro, and the beautiful chaos of raising the best kids in the world, it can be hard to (Madonna voice) keep it together. But you know what helps? Friends like Busy. I love her truly madly deeply. She’s been there for me from the moment we became friends. We’ve been through so much together and we talk about a lot of it in the episode. And thank you to the hilarious and truly generous Caissie St. Onge who did a much better job of plugging my book(s) on the episode than I did. Now go listen to the episode as you order your copy Only This Beautiful Moment please!

Strike Week One. Feet are sore. Knees are achy. Back hurts, and so does my heart when I think of all the greed in this world. But each day on the picket line was filled with community, and in community there is strength. You know who doesn’t have community? Fucking AI. They can train robots to write like Nora Ephron. They can give themselves exorbitant bonuses while they tell us they have no money for writers. But they can’t take our community of creative spirits away. Most of the people in these photos are people I’ve been lucky to create with, from my Ordinary Joe family to my former writing partner Micah to one of our Menendez Brothers Myko to the brilliant Annie Weisman. This industry, like all industries, is made up of people. Not machines. Not data. People with hearts and souls and the fire that creativity comes from, the same fire we’ll fight with. If you have a question about the writers strike please ask me or another writer. There’s a lot of misinformation out there. I spoke to @variety about it all recently, and here’s the quote they used: 
✊🏽
“I’m feeling a mix of sadness and rage. Sad because I want to be doing what I love, which is telling stories. Angry because I’ve watched as corporate greed has slowly and systematically devalued the work of writers and all artists in our society. I’ve been a WGA writer for two decades now, and I’ve seen these changes happen. I believe with all my heart that the arts are one of the most important jobs out there and that artists should be compensated fairly for their work. I also believe that what we’re seeing in Hollywood shouldn’t be covered as an industry issue. We’re seeing work devalued all over the world, in all industries. This is about more than writers. It’s about how we value human labor, it’s about the truly alarming rise in wealth disparity, it’s about keeping unions strong so we can revitalize our middle class, and it’s about standing up to corporate greed, which impacts everyone everywhere these days. At their best, the arts guide us closer to empathy and oneness. That’s what our industry should represent and stand for, and it’s what almost all of the writers I know stand for.”
✊🏽
#WGASTRONG.

I'm just an author, splitting in front of potential readers, asking them to buy his new novel... (which begins with the line, "Being gay on the internet is exhausting.")
📚
No, seriously. Go get a copy of ONLY THIS BEAUTIFUL MOMENT then come back to stare at a 46-year old who does everything he can to remain emotionally and physically flexible. There's a link in my bio to make it easy for you.
📚
Oh, you're back. Thanks for buying the book! Look, life's been a lot lately. I've gone through the emotional experience of having my book LIKE A LOVE STORY banned in multiple states (and the threats and allegations that come with it). I'm walking a picket line for fair wages as a screenwriter as I launch a book in the U.S. and another one in Brazil. My aging body is constantly rebelling against the way my hopefully-forever-young brain likes to take to the sky, but also... life has never felt more beautiful. Social media is a hard place to convey the moments of joy that make life worth fighting for. Like the sound and smell of our kids baking in the kitchen as I write this, with Lana singing an ode to her family in the background. Like the laughter from inside jokes with my husband that no one else would get. Like the sense of community I feel with fellow artists these days because we're being attacked by fascists, and the sense of community I feel with the queer community these days 'cause we're being attacked by fascists, and the sense of community I feel with fellow Iranians these days because we're being... ok, you get it. There's a spreading wave of fascism and fear-based division in the world, and we need to fight back with love, connection, joy, family, friendship, laughter, art. And that's exactly what this book is about. It's everything I love in a book. Iranian and queer history, music and tennis and Hollywood and drag. It's an ode to the power of families that keep it together, to enduring friendships, and to the eternal fight for human freedom.
📚
If you've gotten this far, you better buy a copy for a friend too. I love and thank you all. Now go practice your splits because That! Feels Good!

📷: Rumi

Scene 1: Breakfast. Me: “Should I post this?” Rumi: “It’s kind of basic.” Me: “What’s basic about it? I’m reading my new book upside down.” Rumi: “You do what you do.”
😭
Scene 2: Evie enters: “I think you should zoom in more so people see the book.” Me: “But my legs sell books.” Evie: “I think your face sells books.” 
😭
And that’s our amazing kids in two scenes! Look the world feels upside down right now and a lot of the reasons why are in this book. But my son took this photo and my dad called yesterday to say he’s a hundred pages in and loves it, and this book is about three generations of men in an Iranian family coming together despite profound differences, and maybe bringing generations together is part of turning the world right side up. If you’re reading ONLY THIS BEAUTIFUL MOMENT, thank you. 
📚🙏🏽
And yes you’ll be getting more content from this photo shoot. Apologies in advance. As I told Rumi, I’m not an influencer or model, just a writer doing my best.

STRIKE PHOTOS & THOUGHTS: Parenting, picketing, launching a new novel, diverticulitis, it was a special week. Maybe you saw the video I posted of my incredible friend Simran celebrating my book via bullhorn on the picket line. That only-this-beautiful-moment encapsulates so much of what made this week special. Seeing generosity and unity everywhere, especially on the picket line. On Thursday, the WGA MENA (Middle East / North Africa) group stormed Netflix. Do you know what percentage of employed writers in Hollywood are MENA? ZERO POINT THREE. Round it down and that's 0%. You know what percentage of MENA characters on television are portrayed as terrorists, soldiers or tyrants? SEVENTY-EIGHT PERCENT. According to the UCLA 2022 Diversity Report, you know how many MENA leads there were in films? ZERO. You know why I started writing books and keep writing them? Because I was unsuccessful every time I tried to get a project about my own people made in Hollywood, and remain unsuccessful in getting any of my books adapted, despite superstar producers and directors and in some cases, actual-actor-superstars lending their names to the projects. That's the reality we're faced with, and it's part of this fight. We're fighting for artists to be compensated fairly (and by extension, for all humans to be compensated fairly), but also to be valued for who we are, to be seen. That's what art should do, shine a light on our specificities to unite us in common humanity. I'm so proud to be a queer Iranian storyteller. I'm proud that my new novel ends during the 2019 Iranian protests and hopefully helps people understand the context of the current protest movement in Iran (and America's role in all of it). I'm proud that the novel tells the story of three Iranian men and their journey navigating this world. I hope someday, when this strike ends, I get to see it made into a limited series with a whole bunch of MENA storytellers in the very-well-compensated, very-residual-heavy, very-mentorship-driven maxi-room. #WGASTRONG #zanzendegiazadi #onlythisbeautifulmoment

On the left, the radiant light that is Elisa Donovan upside down, reading Like a Love Story and Only This Beautiful Moment. When I was quoting Amber from Clueless non-stop in my very-early 20s (“We’re going to Melrose” often escaped my lips), I never imagined a moment like this. Here’s what Elisa said in her post: “Inspired by abdaddy, I challenge YOU to read a banned book or a book of your choice upside down. Let’s flip the script on censorship and start a trend that celebrates the freedom of literature.” Now I don’t know if you can do a handstand, but if you can, LET’S MAKE THIS A THING. Flip the damn script on censorship. It’s time for a new perspective. Thank you Elisa, your kindness is so beautiful ❤️🙏🏽

On the right are some recent headlines from the book banning madness including the most insidious piece of “journalism” which implies that a teacher in Maine sexaully abusing a 15-year old is in part due to LIKE A LOVE STORY and other “sexually explicit” books being in the school library. What the full fuck? For the record, my novel THE CHANDLER LEGACIES is about teens in a boarding school standing up to the culture of abuse. Like a Love Story is about teens standing up to the injustice and homophobia of the Reagan years. Maybe the book banners are afraid of young people having any power or agency. Or maybe it’s just good old-fashioned hate. Rebranded Anita Bryant / Briggs Initiative bullshit. Prejudice in a shiny new package with buzzwords like “parental rights” and “Moms for Liberty.” It’s Coke Zero. Zero empathy, zero curiosity, zero love. A braver author than me got their hands on one of the documents being privately circulated about our books. For LIKE A LOVE STORY, the cover page reads, “This book contains... alternate sexualities.” That says it all, no? 

“Hate is just fear in drag.” - LIKE A LOVE STORY

“The most important four-letter word in our history will always be LOVE. That’s what we are fighting for. That’s who we are. Love is our legacy.” - LIKE A LOVE STORY

I have no graphic design skills so apologies for this not-very-beautiful attempt at sharing the humbling all-starred reviews for ONLY THIS BEAUTIFUL MOMENT. Yes, stars from Booklist, Kirkus, Publisher's Weekly, BCCB and Bookpage, which in one gorgeously written review compared the book to my favorite play of all time (Angels in America) and my favorite TV show of all time (Veneno). I mean, what? Reader reviews (so far) have been just as kind. Look, not everything I've done has gotten this kind of acclaim, and lord knows even I don't love a lot of my own stuff, but I LOVE THIS BOOK. It's my favorite thing I've ever written, and the most personal, so seeing it embraced means the world. And as humbling as it is, I also feel like it's important for creatives to not be so humble all the time. I've worked my ass off for over two decades both at growing into my craft and at navigating the business of storytelling. I've learned a lot along the way, about art, humanity, resilience, and I genuinely poured it all into this book, which is about everything I love most: Iranian culture, queer culture, family, art, poetry, Joan Crawford. If the reviews convince you to read it and spread the word, they've done their job.

ONLY THIS BEAUTIFUL MINOGUE. I got to spend a blissful out-of-body minute with one of my favorite artists of all time, the soundtrack of my childhood and now of our kids' childhood, the one and only Kylie Minogue. I got to tell her about how Rumi once brought the lyric book for her album Golden to school for "bring your favorite book to school day," and how we named our dog Disco in part thanks to her album of the same name. And most importantly, I thanked her for bringing genuine joy to our family. Oh, and I gave her a copy of LIKE A LOVE STORY because she does make an appearance in it on Uncle Stephen's list of notecards. No history of queer culture is complete without Kylie. A one-of-a-kind icon of kindness and glitter pop. I love her, and surprising the kids with the signed record to our whole family (including Disco obV) at school pickup was so fun. I'm still buzzing with excitement. Get used to these photos of my moment with pop royalty, 'cause I'll be trotting them out again and often. THANK YOU KYLIE!!

Rare is the celebrity death that genuinely brings me to tears (yes I cry a lot I’m not a typical male). Tina leaving us feels like a monumental moment, a passage into a new era. I never got to see her live but she was always there. There as a rebellious voice in the background of my childhood, there as a testament to the resilience of human beings as I got older, there as a beacon of light and fight. She was truly a hero in a world that needs another hero, always. She lived life right. I hope her passing helps us look deep inside to reconnect with our history, our goodness, our fire, our creativity. Tina forever and ever 🙏🏽💔

Had the best trip to Paris. C’est too much for un post so here are my Paris Chronicles Part 1: Musique, starting with SHYGIRL, who sits comfortably alongside Lana and twigs as one my favorite artists of this millennium. Minutes into arriving, we strolled by a bistro and there she was. I was jet-lagged and starstruck. I obviously had to tell her that Rumi would make me play her song Shlut every time we drove by a billboard for The Crown, and then we'd sing Shlut AS Queen Elizabeth. You should try it. Shy was divine. She even made a video for the kids. I fucking LOVE her. 

Okay, onto BEYONCÉ because seeing her in Paris was epique. What a fucking artist. She absolutely ruled that crowd, which from what I could tell was mostly Americans who bought Paris tickets because unlike in America, tickets there aren't a rigged scam. America Has A (Ticketmaster) Problem. Not that there weren't rabid French fans. The girl behind me screamed every lyric into my ear in the thickest French accent, which was très special. En tout cas, the show was a master class in pop magic (scroll for some highlights). I lost my mind when she paid tribute to Tina Turner, when she sang her heart out during Dangerously in Love, when she took us to queer heaven for the majority of the show, and most of all when she sang my fave, Heated (you can hear me screaming that Uncle Johnny line in the video). 

Speaking of political pop mastery, I couldn't deal with Beyoncé having the words QUEEN MOTHER MADONNA flash onscreen as she sang Vogue. Too much for my gay heart, as was Lucky Records, a store that’s 50% record shop, 50% Madonna museum, 100% heaven. We left that place with bags full of French vinyl (Mylène, Jeanne Mas, Clara Luciani) and some rare Madonna and Kylie. We took a picture with the True Blue gold record, 'cause that's our wedding song 💙

Obviously we bought lots of DALIDA. The ultimate French icon. One of my first musical obsessions. A uniquely global artist. We had to go to Place Dalida to pay homage. I had a moment of reverence with her Montmartre statue and her spirit.

More from Paris soon, but now it's time to keep the music playing at our son's orchestra concert...

On dermatologist-who-burned-benign-stuff-off-my-face’s orders I won’t be at today’s Beyoncé themed WGA picket, but you best believe the kids and I made a T-shirt just for the occasion and turned the iron-on letter project into a dance party. I’ve seen a lot of blame out there on writers for the price of the strike, and while I genuinely feel sick about everyone impacted, please do your research and think through who is really to blame. Stay clear about who needs to be accountable in this industry and in this dangerously corrupt global economy.

Epic Pride Book Tour was magic. Thank you HarperCollins & Epic Reads for standing by your queer authors in a big way. A guide:

1) NYC stop at Books of Wonder with the extraordinary authors Sonora, Ashley, Eliot, Jason June, and our incredible moderator Jacob Demlow who brought the joy.

2) Decatur event at Charis Books & More, one of my favorite bookshops. Thank you to the LEGEND Becky Albertalli for moderating. Becky opened doors for so many of us, myself included, and is the kindest supporter of other authors. Julian Winters, you were with us in spirit and we gave some of your books to the attendees ❤️

3) Our DC event with the PhD himself, Tony Keith Jr, who I could listen to forever. Thanks for making our DC stop feel so alive, Tony.

4) Getting in hair and makeup for our press day, and sitting in the studio doing interview after interview. I lost track of who we spoke to, but I do know that my husband's aunt saw us on Good Morning America in Toledo, so you know what, we're STARS.

5) Backstage shenanigans in the Epic Reads green room while filming social media content. Sydney Sweeney and The Idol were definitely discussed. 

6) One of the most special parts of the trip was a Pride panel for HarperCollins employees. We all got to meet the people responsible for creating our books and getting them read. I couldn't be more appreciative that Harper took the time to get to know us better. Photos are with my beloved editor Alessandra Balzer and cover designer Julia Feingold. 

7) The iconic Jason June and I recreating an And Just Like That moment because in addition to loving The Idol, I'll be loyal to Carrie Bradshaw forever.

8) A little more from the dynamic trio who went from bookshop to bookshop signing. The bottom picture is from one of my favorites, the Strand in NYC. You can find a lot of signed books from all three of us in NYC, DC and Decatur.

9 & 10) Some of the family and friends in NYC who made me feel very loved and supported.

Go read our books won’t you?

Happy Father’s Day to us and to our dads and to all the daddies out there. We got the best and the worst gift from them today. The best: a song written just for us. The worst: they’re off to sleep-away camp. But really that’s the best too because it means we’ve prepared them to fly into their own independent adventures which is what the magical heartbreaking beauty of parenting is all about.

I’ve been reunited with my 2008 WGA strike wood stake (is stake the right word? I swear I don’t know how I make my living writing in a language I still have trouble comprehending). In any case, the fabulous writer, WGA Captain and cinephile @moviesmovington found the stake (or whatever the right word is) at the Fox lot and now it’s mine again. I inscribed it on January 8, 2008, in a different world than this one. Just scroll to the last picture and look at my phone to get a sense of how much has changed. The velocity of time and our ability to hold the people we once were inside the people we are now consumes me these days. It’s what my latest book is about (go buy Only This Beautiful Moment please). It’s what the new movie Past Lives is about and that’s a perfect film I’ll be begging you to watch many times. Anyway it’s a lovely thing to hold the stake I once held again, and to ponder how I and the world have changed since then, back when mini-rooms didn’t exist and AI was still science fiction. Photo 1 was a few hours ago. The rest of the photos are from 2007-2008. But what is time anyway? Another word I have trouble comprehending. #WGASTRONG

Happy birthday to the artist whose poetry and melodies haunt my subconscious life, and most of my conscious life too. To me, she is THE artist of these fucked-up times. Lana is wisely off Instagram again so she won’t see me butcher her magic, but honestly playing these melodies on piano when I didn’t start learning any instrument deep into my adult years is such a joy. Aging people of the world, I highly recommend being an eternal student and challenging your brain to keep learning new things. Thank you Lana for creating art that is so pure and transcendent, and for connecting me to humanity and God and vulnerability as the world feels lost to technology and commodification-of-the-soul and greed. I fell in love with you at first sight with your very first video for Video Games, and now I play the song on piano almost every day to soothe my anxious mind and whisk myself off into your dream world. I love you the first time, I love you the last time. You are my princesa, jazz singer, cult leader, I love you forever. Don’t come back to Instagram. Take your vape wherever the spirit moves you to go and stay inspired ‘cause the culture needs you and I need you more.

Some recent highlights from author-life that aren't about that The NY Times article, ha. A guide:

1. ONLY THIS BEAUTIFUL MOMENT launch in LA with my most beloved. Underneath us are two of my favorite recent pieces of press. One is an article from The Boston Globe about, what else, book bans. The journalist, Jorja Siemons, took the time to speak to me for a long time and the care Jorja took shows in the article. On the right, recommendations from Oxfam (!!) where I'm next to my favorite author of all time, James Baldwin.

2. Some highlights from The Boston Globe article and a photo at The Strand with fellow Epic Pride authors Sonora Reyes and Jason June. The Strand is where I had my first-ever book reading. It'll always be a special place to me.

3. Disco at the LA book reading. He was 100% guard-dogging, probably 'cause he hears us talk about the bans and threats. This dog definitely understands us. On the right: LitHub breaking news, I'm happy to be queer!

4. Like a Love Story alternate cover from a student whose class had to redesign the cover for their English final. This is "Reza as Madonna," which is really me as Madonna, which is MY ULTIMATE DREAM. Thank you for sharing this and letting me share it, Diana.

5. Bracelets gifted to me by the kindest reader at our NYC stop at Books of Wonder. Each of the bracelets Juliette made is related to my books. Zoom in to see, but some say the book titles, others have character names or quotes. Sharing these with the kids when I got home from the tour was very special.

6. We were on Kansas public radio! Also on the news in places like Huntsville and Portland and I-don't-know-where-else 'cause that studio day was a blur. But my husband's aunt saw us on Good Morning America in Toledo and that's pretty damn cool.

7. The lovely booksellers of Annabelle's Book Club LA, who chose the book as their first official book club pick! Plus a list from Kirkus.

8. Book-ban news, starred reviews, Iranian support. I appreciate it all, even the hate. As the Queen said (@madonna obV), "If you don't like me and still watch everything I do. Bitch, you're a fan."

How lucky am I? I get to interview the best people.

@abdaddy and I had such a great convo and I can’t wait for you to listen. Abdi’s writing is so beautiful and crucial for anyone who wants to feel a deep connection to queer stories.

Abdi Nazemian (he/him/his) is the author of five novels, including his latest, Only This Beautiful Moment. For his literary work, he has received a Lambda Literary Award and a Stonewall Honor, and his novel Like a Love Story was selected by Time as one of the 100 best young adult books of all time. His screenwriting credits include the films The Artist's Wife, The Quiet, and Menendez: Blood Brothers, and numerous television series. His producing credits include Call Me By Your Name, Little Woods, and Scotty and the Secret History of Hollywood.
