On the last day of Pride Month, as the Supreme-ish Court strips our rights away, I wanted to take a moment to celebrate how special this year’s LA Pride was for our family. Special because my brilliant husband @aubryla1 and his @aubryandco team helped put it all together. Special because we got to take the world’s self-proclaimed number 1 Megan Thee Stallion fan (also our son) to see her live, and got to invite two of our kids’ besties to see the shows and meet some of their favorite drag queens and Taylor Swift music video stars. Special because three of the headliners on the stage (Megan, Gigi, Symone) incorporated my forever-queen Madonna into their act, a reminder that Madonna is always with our community even when she can’t be with us, and we’re always with her (especially right now). Here are some memories and moments. Stay strong and connected to community. The forces of division are trying to shame our Pride and that just means we need to keep up the energy not for a month but year-round, all over this earth, always. Happy fucking Pride millennium.

Reading my way through Provincetown, Dublin and Lisbon, 3 places with real reverence for writers. Provincetown, America's oldest continuous art colony. Dublin, where you can't turn a corner without encountering Joyce, Wilde, Yeats, and where new writers are equally celebrated. The Museum of Literature Ireland had a Young Adult Literature exhibit, and had this to say: "Just as James Joyce reflected the realities of Irish society, Young Adult Fiction writers give readers an insight into the real challenges facing young people in Ireland, and around the world, today." I was deeply moved by this (the literary community at home rarely takes us seriously). Fuck yeah, we're the new James Joyces of the world (last photo is me signing books at East End Books in Provincetown as shameless promo). And finally, Lisbon, where my hotel was themed after a writer (Pessoa, of course), where the world's oldest operating bookshop stands. Look, I'm sure a different voyager would visit these same places and find different connective tissue (Alcohol? I genuinely don't know how people handle all the booze...) But from my perspective, as an author traveling while also on strike as a screenwriter, it was very moving to observe reverence for writers everywhere. It was a reminder that the work artists do moves people (we hope), transcends time (we hope), and unites people (we hope). 
📚
Also, just as I was leaving Los Angeles to escape the loneliness of the kids being at sleepaway as I was on strike, one of the trades published a piece about how writers are agonizing over whether to go away (I didn’t), and whether to post about it (I will). Taking time for yourself was portrayed as an insensitive breach of solidarity. Our culture is genuinely obsessed with guilt and shame, which I feel none of. I've done and will continue to do my time on the picket lines. If anyone should feel guilt and shame, it's the forces of power in both corporate boardrooms and government halls who have allowed this world (and specifically tech companies) to strip humans and artists of dignity. More stories from my travels very soon, including the most summertime sadness James Joyce tale of all time.

A short story about me, James Joyce, and Elizabeth Woolridge Grant. You probably know I've had a healthy obsession with Lana Del Rey since her first video. You may also know I love Joyce, especially Dubliners, which Andrew Scott reads to me so often that his perfect Irish voice lives in my head saying things like "dusty cretonne."
I
So, Lana announces a surprise show in Dublin during my trip. I get a GA ticket, thinking Lana's fans will be like me, midlife gays who calmly cry in corners. 
I
I land early, wander into a magical place, Sweny's. It's the pharmacy from Ulysses, now a shop run by the amazing PJ, who plays me a song from Dubliners, pulls out Ulysses in Persian, sells me lemon soap (as featured in Ulysses) that I wash myself with obsessively in hopes genius seeps in.
I
Concert Day at Sweny's. We read my favorite story Eveline aloud. Communal Joyce readings are a daily ritual there. A Ulysses reading begins but I have museums to visit. The show is WILDE. TikTok has transformed her audience. I’m the oldest human in the scorching venue, poignant when Lana sings, "Will you still love me when I'm no longer young and beautiful?" I fan myself with my Dubliners pocket-guide. The girl next to me passes out. The teens scream EVERY lyric. Hearing Irish straight men, arms around girlfriends, scream "Goddamn man child, you fucked me so good that I almost said I love you." Well, it’s progress. 
I
Then, Lana says she ran into a group reading Ulysses earlier and joined. I don’t pass out (that's for the teens) but I cry in a corner. 
I
Last day in Dublin, PJ tells me how kind she was, and her guide (the lovely Pat Liddy) is there, shows me his photo with her. I sign the guest book above her, paraphrasing my favorite Eveline quote.
I
I convince myself that missing Lana is punishment for never reading Ulysses. But I'm glad it happened this way. It keeps her an unattainable goddess in my world. Someday, I hope to hear her on an Irish street reading the words "dusty cretonne," but not yet. That feels like the end of a story. I'm gonna try to, finally, read Ulysses, maybe. But if I don't, I'll still wash myself with all the lemon soap I brought home.

A tribute to some of Ireland’s mind-blowing artists.

Róisín Murphy!! Been obsessed with her music since the Moloko days but had never seen her live. Kind of glad, ‘cause I don’t know that anything could compare to seeing her in her home country, on the campus where Oscar Wilde, Bram Stoker and Samuel Beckett once studied. If you ever have a chance to see her perform, take it. It’s an overpowering experience. 

Veda Lady. I was introduced to Veda by the divine creative force that is Maria McKee. We had a lovely coffee and Veda gave me advice on what to do and where to eat (Octopussy in Howth, beyond!). That night, I went to Witchy Wednesdays at The George, Veda’s weekly drag show. Everyone in Veda’s coven of performers was incredible. And unsurprisingly, since Veda is also an HIV activist, the show was brilliantly political. Turning Adele’s Someone Like You into Someone Like U=U equals genius. Did you see the enraging article about Gilead in today’s New York Times? Read it. We need activists around this globe fighting against corporate greed, shame, stigma. I appreciate you, Veda Lady.

Grian Chatten, lead singer of Fontaines D.C, perhaps the only band that could get me into a mosh pit. I love them. I love his new solo record, which I listened to non-stop in Dublin. He’s just a brilliant musician, lyricist, poet, performer, and also my number two celebrity crush (behind Omar Apollo obviously, with Father John Misty close behind).

I already shared some of the Irish books I read, all brilliant, but also want to shout out the classic Irish folk band Tír na nÓg, who I’d never heard of before this trip, and am now so in love with. In addition to Grian and Róisín, they were in heavy rotation during my time there. 

And a big shout out to everyone involved with the play Waiting For The Offo, which I absolutely loved. I really appreciated that so much of the art I encountered from current Irish artists is grappling with the country’s intense alcohol intake. This play grappled hilariously and brilliantly.

Forever in awe of Irish artists and of the enormous cultural footprint of this small country.

This portrait of me was taken by the incredible Michelle Schapiro, in Provincetown, on the beach just past East End Books, where we met because she'd read Like a Love Story thanks to Busy's podcast (gratitude for @busyphilipps @instacais). The tattoo in the 2nd slide is from a Like a Love Story reader, inspired by the novel, which moved me deeply. Now a story:

Michelle was in town for a photography workshop at the Fine Art Works Center and asked to take my photo. She suggested the cemetery and I said no, 'cause though I've worked on it, I'm still deeply superstitious. I'm very happy about that because moments before the photo shoot, news broke that Madonna was hospitalized and unresponsive. If I were striking a pose in a cemetery when that happened, I would not have been okay. 

The photo was part of a showcase at FAWC, where Lauren and I got to hear Andrea Lawlor & Melissa Febos speak, and I got to accost one of my favorite authors Alexander Chee. I met Oliver Baez Bendorf there, who was teaching the workshop on Queer/Trans Ecopoetry (sign me up) and who was coincidentally reading Like a Love Story that week. It felt so special to feel like a small part of this community of artists, which included Chloe Feffer from Lambda Literary, who has helped book so many of my school visits. 

Earlier on picture day, I was walking in a torrential downpour, and Gary Garrison from the then-closed Provincetown Theater saw me seeking refuge under the awning. He invited me in, gave me a tour, let me play Tori Amos on piano and read Oscar Wilde quietly while he worked. It felt warm in there. 

At some point during this trip, I melted down, as I did last year after the kids went to sleepaway. Empty nest is brutal. I think part of the breakdown(s) were/are related to wondering where I belong and who I am when I'm not a parent. The sense of belonging I felt among this community of queer artists who showed me so much kindness felt necessary. I hope everyone gets to feel true belonging, and also that everyone finds a photographer who makes them feel like James Dean for one frame.

And so my Bloomsdays begin on Venice Beach, Dublin and Marilyn on my mind. Anyone want to join me in reading Ulysses? I took my shirt off to convince you to join the, um, fun. Look, I know this is Instagram and most of us (e.g. me) come here for hot tatted guys and Lana or whatever your version of hot tatted guys and Lana is (cute cats and sunsets?) but what better way to resist the fast-twitch attention economy than by reading one of the most daunting books ever. 

I begin this literary odyssey afraid and intimidated but with a plan. Since PJ from Sweny’s told me the book is meant to be read aloud, I’m listening to the Jim Norton narrated audio book as I read along. After each chapter, I go to Patrick Hastings’ Guide to Ulysses for context or just to tell me what the fuck I just read. Three chapters in and I think it’s a good plan.

And yes I’m mostly posting this ‘cause publicly stating my intention to finally read the book makes me less likely to put it off another year. A pandemic made me read Proust and a strike will make me read Ulysses.

"I'll remember it. Dublin in a rainstorm." I heard Sinéad sing those words from her masterpiece Yeats-referencing song, Troy, in my head on every Dublin walk. I've been hearing Sinéad in my head since I was a kid. Her lyrics swirl inside me. "And of course I'm like a wild horse but there's no other way I could be." "I get sexy underneath the lights like I wanna fuck every man in sight." "Remember what I told you: If they hated me they will hate you." "I'm not no animal in the zoo. I'm not no whipping boy for you." She was my first exposure to the serenity prayer, which I thought she wrote, and which I thought then and still think are the wisest words ever written. She offered our generation artistic defiance, musical magic, political bravery. She was a gateway to Ireland, a land that has fascinated me for so long (a fellow Middle Eastern writer and I realized we share this obsession and concluded that Irish storytelling was the closest we got to a version of our own experience in the west). Our son gives me shit for saying everyone is one of my favorites, but she really was (and as I tell him, wouldn't you rather have too many favorites than not enough?). She was my last pre-pandemic concert. That voice remained a gut-punch. There's a whole scene in the book I'm currently writing about her album of Irish folk songs, which I love, and which is unavailable to stream (keep your records and CDs, and don't expect that scene to make the final edit). You can listen to her version of Paddy's Lament on YouTube though, the live version is my favorite. There are few things more moving than Sinéad singing, "There is nothing here but war, where the murderin' cannons roar, and I wish I was at home in dear old Dublin." RIP Sinéad. The photo of me is on the Trinity campus in Sinead's Dublin a few weeks ago, where I was reading Irish fiction and chasing the voices of all the Irish artists who have inspired me, starting with Sinéad, who I hope is in some heavenly version of dear old Dublin now. There is no other Troy for us to burn.

August. Still on strike. Grateful for the community of humans who make heat-wave-picketing bearable. I have nothing to say that’s wiser than the excerpts below from Inkoo Kang’s New Yorker piece, but I do think it’s depressingly hilarious that the article uses The Little Mermaid as an example when I keep imagining the AMPTP as Ursula, trying to steal hands and hearts and voices, voices, hearts and hands. See what I did there? Quoted a classic film in discussing another classic film. Because I LOVE film. I love TV. I love storytelling and artists so fucking deeply, and this industry should be run by people who love it and us too, not by Big Tech Ursulas who see us all (yes even you) as Discardable Data. We need people ready to restore respect and humanity to the inevitably uneasy relationship between art and commerce. Some excerpts:

“The streaming wars, of which writers and actors rightly see themselves as collateral damage, have introduced players like Apple and Amazon, for whom content is only a tiny portion of their broader business strategies—a value-add for iPhone users or Prime subscribers. Together with Netflix, the move-fast, break-things, maybe-fix-later crowd has brought with it the Silicon Valley playbook of burning up investor or reserve cash now in the hopes of profit tomorrow, and in the process has forced some of Hollywood’s most storied studios, most notably Disney and Warner Bros., into billions in debt to stay competitive.”

“The movies may be in grimmer shape. The industry’s pursuit of I.P. at the expense of originality has all but trained younger audiences not to expect novelty or surprise at the multiplex, assuming that they’re going to the theatre at all. Hollywood has never been known for overestimating the audience’s intelligence, but it’s hard not to wonder how it is supposed to be inculcating a love of cinema in children—that is, future moviegoers—when the splashiest films on offer are explicitly buckets of regurgitation. Early summer gave us the live-action “Little Mermaid,” the latest in Disney’s cannibalization of its archives.”

#wgastrong #sagaftra

100 days of the writers strike, and I've never believed more in the importance of this movement, not just for writers and actors, but for all workers who are seeing their dignity stripped away by this era of big tech and corporate greed (seriously, if you don't think this impacts all industries, go listen to The Daily episode about the moral dilemma of America's doctors as they're faced with working for private equity firms or mega-corporations, it's chilling). I've been inspired by Fran Drescher's leadership and incredible ability to communicate the issues, so here’s a little Fran story. Fran starred in a 2003 movie I co-wrote for ABC Family, back when that was a network and some still believed the internet would create a new utopia instead of further consolidation of power. When the shoot ended, no wrap party was planned. Fran stepped in and threw a wrap party herself, including everyone who labored on the project. Little moments from that party have morphed from lived experience into anecdotes, like Fran grabbing a plate of olives and saying, "Why aren't the olives moving? If we were in Spain, the olives would be moving." The rest of the details have been lost to memory, like the movie itself, which isn't available to watch, which is fine by me. I'm sure it's not great, but if memory serves, we snuck in the words "Linda Televangelista" in there, and that's enough for me. The point is that Fran cared about the writers, cast, crew, and when she found out we wouldn't be celebrated, she did something about it. And that's what we need more of. We need people at the top of every industry, every set, every workplace, who care about the dignity and well-being of the workers within that industry, set, workplace, and in turn they'll be rewarded by workers willing to put their heart and soul into their work (see: "Linda Televangelista"). Thank you Fran, and thank you to everyone who loves our industry and supports its workers. If you want to help get funds to people affected by the strikes, you can donate to the Entertainment Community Fund (@alifeinthearts) or to @joelle_garfinkel’s Green Envelope Grocery Aid (Venmo @Joelle-Garfinkel). #wgastrong #sagaftra

Happy birthday Madonna. She's been a part of every phase of my life that I can remember. My childhood, my kids' childhoods, my wedding, the big and the small moments, all made possible in part by the strength she gifted me, the fearlessness, rebelliousness, curiosity, creativity, and spirituality she taught me to live with. I remember being seven years old, seeing the Lucky Star video, and knowing exactly where I belonged. I remember being eight years old, and forcing my parents to take me to The Virgin Tour. At thirteen, I made them take me to Blond Ambition (from Like a Love Story: "If the world could bring together this woman with these songs and these dancers in this place with me in it, then creation must be more powerful than destruction”). I remember getting my sex ed from her because the sex ed class I took told me I would die, as she was teaching me how to live. So many memories. I could go on and on and on. A little over a month ago in Provincetown, the day that news of her hospitalization broke, I said it felt like a family member being in the hospital and some guy I don't know said, "That's crazy." Fair enough, but among the many things Madonna taught me is that one's relationship to art should be deep, and that I don't care how others perceive me. I was raised to conform, and I've never wanted that. Crazy works for me, and I'm crazy for her, always. This morning, I got a Google alert that those Moms 4 Liberty are trying to ban Like a Love Story in yet another district. That book is an ode to her ("the opposite of shame is Madonna") but it's not enough. There is no enough when it comes to Madonna. There's always more to say, more to discover, more to appreciate and discuss and argue about and and and. I love you, Madonna. Your name will always be an incantation to me, a reminder to express every part of myself and to never stop digging deeper and deeper into everything this world has to offer us.

Happy birthday Tori Amos, goddess of catharsis, savior of tortured souls everywhere. First 5 photos are favorite Tori moments through the pretty good years. Last 5 are highlights from the last time I saw her at The Greek (thanks for the best birthday present @busyphilipps). Everyone’s entry point into Tori obsession is different. For me true love hit on a trip to Italy in the late ‘90s. This was in pre-iPod days when you had to choose which CDs to travel with. I chose Tori’s From The Choirgirl Hotel as one of two CDs and listened to pretty much nothing else on that trip. Since then, Tori has been an essential part of my life, my vocabulary, and so many of my friendships. Her music has created a real community and she cares for that community with genuine love and authentic artistry. It’s a beautiful thing. I’ve seen her live more than anyone else. I’ve cried to her music, raged to it, healed because of it. She’s so important to me that anyone who hires me to write or speak has to write a check to Boy for Pele Inc. Now doesn’t that make you wanna hire me?

ONLY THIS BEAUTIFUL MOMENT now has an Educators’ Guide, brilliantly crafted by shea wesley martin and Nawal Qarooni, two superstars who inspire me and who do a lot to make the world a better place for students and educators. The guide is free to use and share, and is a resource for teachers who want to teach the book. If you’d like a copy emailed to you for yourself or for any educators you may know, please DM me and it shall be done. It can also be found on the book’s HarperCollins landing page. LIKE A LOVE STORY and THE CHANDLER LEGACIES also have Educators’ Guides, also free to use and share.

The most personally gratifying part of writing these novels for me has been school visits with classrooms who read the books. These conversations have taught me so much, and hopefully taught the students something too. With all the focus on book banning (yes, it’s still happening… a lot), I also want to help shine a light on all the brave, open-hearted educators who are bringing queer books into their classrooms, and facilitating engaging discussions about pieces of our history that are rarely taught.

Thanks in advance to everyone supporting the new book. Photos are at Book Passage in the Ferry Building in San Francisco. When I told the kids how excited I was to see the book on the shelves, Evie said my book(s) are on the shelf of almost every bookstore we go into, and while that’s not entirely true (I wish it was), the truth is it never isn’t exciting to see the work on bookstore or library shelves, which I guess means I’m doing something I genuinely love and believe in, and I’m very grateful for that.

I’ve been terrible about keeping up with social media lately, so big thanks to everyone posting, reading, reviewing. Books succeed on word of mouth. Shout about the ones you love. 

📷: @mohpalizi & @suhlizi

Updates for anyone who wants to say hi to me in Rio de Janeiro (!!), Charleston or Palm Springs. 

Sunday September 10, 17h, I’ll be at the Bienal do Livro chatting with Felipe Cabral, Vitor Martins, Patrick Torres and Giu Domingues. That’s a lot of fofura, and I hope you beautiful brasileiros come say olá, I’ve been practicing meu portugues para vocês. 

October 14, I’ll be at Pride on the Page in Palm Springs. The opening night guest is one of my biggest literary heroes Armistead Maupin so I’m freaking out a little (photo 2 is me on the Barbary Lane steps, if you know, you know).

November 10 + 11, I’ll be at Yallfest in Charleston. It’ll be my first time in this stunning city since a very memorable trip there during high school, so please come say hi.

More dates to come on my Salt-And-Pepper Ambition Tour.

Last photos are from recent picketing. Unlike many of my fellow screenwriters, I have author life to keep me feeling creative and purposeful. Please continue to support every screenwriter and actor fighting for fair wages. I love a long-ass caption, and I’m tempted to go on and on about anti-trust laws, US. vs. Paramount, Fin-Syn, and why our industry is one of many in which human dignity is being stripped away by unchecked corporate greed. But I’ll stop here. Do your research. I’m praying that we move a little closer to separation of corporation and state someday soon ‘cause this mega-corporation shit is bananas.

ONLY THIS BEAUTIFUL MOMENT is coming to the UK and Commonwealth on November 2 via Little Tiger (excluding New Zealand and Australia, where the book is already published via University of Queensland Press aaaah). Big thanks to Mattie Whitehead for believing in this book, Charlie Moyer for the cover design, and to Safiya Zerrougui for the gorgeous original artwork. If you follow my adventures, you know that London is where I do a lot of my writing, and where I go for artistic replenishment. It’s also where my dad went to school, and since this is a story about fathers and sons, that makes this book being my first UK book very resonant. 

The photo of me is in the Bishopsgate Institute queer archives during my last London trip. I felt deeply connected to history and community on that day, and I share the photo today because I’m well aware that in addition to being home to vibrant queer life, the UK is also currently home to too much heartbreaking anti-queer, and specifically anti-trans, rhetoric and legislation. I hope everyone with an open heart and a curious mind does their part to combat division and misinformation wherever it rises up, and I hope this book helps spark discussions about how to create change while also building bridges. 

The article clips are from The Bookseller, “at the heart of the book trade since 1858” when Oscar Wilde was a wee four-year old (!!) and a year before Dickens published A Tale of Two Cities (!!), which come to think of it could have been a title for this book about Los Angeles and Tehran through the years and through the eyes of one family. Read it, won’t you?

A little over a week ago, I took my inner gay Iranian cowboy on an artist date to see Zach Bryan, who I absolutely love. This was before his new album came out and began deservedly conquering the world. Some have expressed surprise at me being obsessed with a straight male country singer, and while I get that, my insatiable musical tastes tend to be less aligned by genre and more about finding true artists in the detritus of industry. I can't think of a genre of music I'm not interested in, and I wish the algorithms of the world understood that I don't want to be fed music that sounds just like my other favorites. What I want are true artists, which he is, as is Maggie Rogers, who was TRANSCENDENT with him up there.

When I first fell for his music, I had no idea he was on the right side of two of the issues I care most about. The first: corporate greed. Streaming is pure corruption and Ticketmaster/Live Nation must be broken up. ZB called one of his records All My Homies Hate Ticketmaster, and doesn't work with them, instead setting up his own resale site where fans MUST sell tickets at face value. If anyone understands why every artist doesn't do this, please explain. I figured perhaps record labels forced artists to work with ze evil monopoly, but Zach's with Warner so maybe not. 

Second issue: trans rights. We're at a point where even queer icons are spewing anti-trans conspiracy theories, and here's a country singer calling out his own community for transphobia with words like: "I just think insulting transgender people is completely wrong because we live in a country where we can all just be who we want to be. It’s a great day to be alive." 

To be clear, those aren't the reasons I fell for him. Those would be his poetry, his melodies, his stunning vocals. But they help. And as a bonus, the cowboy crowd at his show was unbearably hot, and they were probably all wondering what the Iranian queen was doing alone in the 8th row playing Wordle and Spelling Bee 'til the show began. Thanks for adding a breath of fresh air to the music industry, Zach. It's a great day to be alive.

 #zachbryan #maggierogers

Photos: Provincetown, June 2023. Words: me and Uncle Stephen, cut from LIKE A LOVE STORY, edited for caption length. Read the book, hopefully in a place you love. If you listen to the audio, Judy’s in these photos.
🌊
"We are explorers. We are discoverers. And we deserve places of our own. It’s not surprising that of all the spots on Cape Cod, this is the one we chose. It’s at the very tip, as far out as you can get. Of course, we would find a place at the very edge of the world, where earth meets water, and say, “This is where we belong!” It’s not a coincidence that it was a lesbian who spoke of needing a room of one’s own. And I think we need even more than one room. I think we need places. Places where we feel free and safe. The world is dangerous for us. It lurks, it hides, we all feel the danger of being ourselves, the looming threats of violence and disease. But in Provincetown, our rights matter. Here, our artists create. Here, our community comes together to put on shows, kiss, love, dance, read, write, paint, screw, and ride those bicycles down Main Street like we’re riding on pink clouds. Here, drag queens own businesses, and are celebrated by the town. Too many of those queens are dead now. Epic, legendary queens. But the place is still there. No matter how many we lose, the edge of this cape will still call to us, will still inspire us to congregate, and we will make new music, and we will also hear the music of those who passed. Because here, we don’t forget our history. Here, bookstores stock their shelves with the work of Virginia Woolf and James Baldwin and Edmund White and Andrew Holleran and Rita Mae Brown and Armistead Maupin and Paul Monette and Randy Shilts and Tennessee Williams, who wrote some of his best plays here. Maybe it was Tennessee who saw this place, this tip, this edge, and said, “THIS. IS. OURS.” The waves on these shores are not the transference of energy from wind to water. They are the transference of energy from our ghosts to their living kin. They are the sound of our history holding us, enveloping us, wrapping us in its arms and making us feel safe, so that we may have the strength we need to keep crashing the shore."
🌊

Virgo’s Groove Beyoncé birthday real-reel. Video is from LA Pride, where an impromptu sing-a-long happened to the Heated rap (best Beyoncé song of all time), bringing a roomful of people together in a liberated-living-like-we-ain’t-got-time moment. I have deep appreciation for true and unique artists who can somehow become monoculture because they give freaks like me unifying moments like this. Nobody in the current culture unites the mainstream to the underground like Bey. Nobody since Madonna has been at expert as making pop political, and does it with profound artistry and larger-than-life magic. Photo is by me in Paris, where Pally & I got to dance in Club Renaissance for face value ‘cause countries that aren’t America have actual regulations on evil monopolies. Those same seats are $7,000 apiece for tonight’s show. This is why virtually everyone in our section in Paris traveled from the U.S. for the show, ‘cause flying to Paris made more sense than paying the Ticketmaster monopoly fees. Utterly despicable shit, especially since artists don’t profit from the fees. In the words of the queen, America Has a Problem. But America also has the ability to create artists who light up the world and we need more of those 👑👑👑 video by Queen @joymaryro

Have you read The Chandler Legacies? 📚

Nothing makes me happier than my books traveling the world thanks to global publishers willing to take a chance on queer literature and the translators who help transform the books. Thrilled to announce - in conjunction with book blogger Paweł Truskolaski - that The Chandler Legacies / Dziedzictwo Chandlera is coming to Poland very soon on September 27, translated by Michał Zacharzewski, published by W.A.B. Kind of amazing to know this story, inspired by my time in the closed environment of boarding school, is flying so far away. Thank you, Poland.

Nic nie sprawia mi większej radości niż podróżowanie po świecie moich książek dzięki globalnym wydawcom, którzy chcą dawać szanse literaturze queer i tłumaczom, którzy pomagają przełożyć moje teksty. We współpracy z blogerem książkowym Pawłem Truskolaskim z radością ogłaszam że już wkrótce - 27 września w Polsce ukaże się "Dziedzictwo Chandlera" w tłumaczeniu Michała Zacharzewskiego, opublikowane przez Wydawnictwo W.A.B. To niesamowite, że ta historia, zainspirowana moim czasem spędzonym w zamkniętym środowisku szkoły z internatem, dociera tak daleko. Dziękuję, Polsko.

First picture: on a Hollywood street last night with one of our favorite drag queens, the pride of Belfast, Blu Hydrangea (cold cash divine…) The rest of the photos are from my summer days in dear old Dublin. Few things inspire me more than drag queens and Irish artists. I’ve been a little more angry than I like to be these days as my books get banned by bigots and stolen by tech companies to train AI. So here are two quotes from my favorite Irishman Oscar Wilde that helped me and may help you. Regarding book bans: “The books that the world calls immoral are books that show the world its own shame.” Yup. Regarding rage: “Always forgive your enemies. Nothing annoys them so much.” Yup.

It’s Banned Books week. Pretty sad that we need to designate a week for the suppression of free speech and thought, but here we (still) are. I’m exhausted by hearing about my book(s) being banned in district after district, and by talking about the banning vs. the actual content of the books. It often feels like we’re allowing fascists to dictate the terms of the conversations we’re having. When I’m exhausted by the world and in need of replenishment, I turn to books. So here’s what I’ve been reading. In these pages, I found escapist romance, teenage rebellion, political wisdom, necessary laughter, cathartic tears and a new love for 1960s Korean music. Go listen to Pearl Sisters immediately.

The books:

Girlhood by @melissafebos 

Miss Major Speaks by @missmajor1 & Toshio Meronek

Crying in H Mart by @jbrekkie

Keeper of the Lost Cities by @sw_messenger (read by Evie, many many many times)

Romantic Comedy by Curtis Sittenfeld

Checkout 19 by Claire-Louise Bennett 

Skater Boy by @anthonynerada 

Pineapple Street by @jennyjacksonpineapple 

#letfreedomread

Even as these books continue to be banned, even as they're being stolen by Big Tech to train the algorithms they hope will replace artists someday, this remains the best job I could dream of. None of this will bring peace to our fractured world. Maybe it’ll create a tiny bit more connection and empathy which is all most of us can do with our moments here. Last night, during a game of Spades, I did my best to answer the kids’ questions about Israel and Palestine, which also meant discussing World War II, the Holocaust, the history of western intervention in the Middle East, the goals of the current Iranian regime, antisemitism, Islamophobia, the fact that governments and political organizations often don’t represent their people, and on and on and on until we went back to playing cards and eating Persian ice cream. If you’re searching for a way to express yourself that goes beyond a hashtag or a repost, try imagining the eyes of innocent curious loving children taking it all in and ask yourself if you want to leave them in a state of vengeance and hatred or of unity and empathy. One love, always 🙏🏽

Took my book to the Trevi Fountain to share the news that in addition to the previously shared best-of lists (New York Public Library, The Guardian, Booklist, Bookpage, Kirkus and more), ONLY THIS BEAUTIFUL MOMENT was also chosen as a best book of the year by The Boston Globe and BCCB. Read it won’t you? But seriously, we were at the Trevi so I could show the kids the fountain I swam in when I was a wild teenager, which led to being chased by the carabinieri but evading them because we knew a secret entrance to the Roman Forum and hid in Titus’ ruins until the cops moved on. Those were magical times, and so are these. We spent the holidays sharing three of our favorite things with the kids: Rome, Paris, and Madonna. Happy to report all three are as magnificent as ever. Allora, I hope this post inspires you to put your phone away and go read a book (mine 😂 but also I highly recommend The Great Circle and my current read The Nix) or go listen to some great new music (loving Popa’s new album Arte e Finanza, a perfect Italian soundtrack) or go see a movie (my recent favorites: Anatomy of a Fall, Past Lives, also Criterion’s James Gray collection is overwhelming). Happy new year beautiful friends. 

📷: Rumi
